channel.title: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?
channel.description: I started thinking about this today after reviewing my notes on string theory in ESS, Earth Space Science, and just realized if their are infinite number of universes with each one of these universes have one thing different from each other..does it mean that what ever we are doing is already determine? Lets say in one universe I play Runescape and in the other universe I play World of Warcraft. In the other universe I was already dentin to play World of Warcraft since that is the small change from that universe to the other. Get what I'm saying? With this idea does it mean what ever we do in this universe is already set-up of what ever we are going to do? So are choices in life is already been determine and no matter what are mind thinks its already set what we are going to choose. Do you guys agree with this?

item.title: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“Sfacciato, post:25, topic:534054”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=652850.msg4384684#msg4384684 date=1384890304]

So in reality, nothing is actually spontaneous. Even computer functions meant to generate a random number aren’t completely random. With that said, if you had an absolute understanding of the universe, then you should be able to predict the outcome of everything.

This alone opens a plethora of paradoxical situations. Is it even possible to conclusively model a system that understands the world around it including its self? If such a system predicts the future then that prediction alone surely influences the actual outcome, invalidating the initial prediction.
[/quote]

Yeah, it was more of a rhetorical question.

An absolute and complete understanding of the universe, if possible, would allow you to predict the outcome of anything and everything; runeite was correct. You would be able to predict the outcome of everything, because you would be able to take into effect the quantum mechanics involved with changing the outcome. I seem to have missed the point of your post in my other post (now deleted), my apologies.[/quote]
If you could predict everything you could predict your own future, correct? But if you could predict your own future, could you change your own future? For you would have predicted yourself trying to change your future.

Read full topic
item.source: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?

So in reality, nothing is actually spontaneous. Even computer functions meant to generate a random number aren’t completely random. With that said, if you had an absolute understanding of the universe, then you should be able to predict the outcome of everything.
[/quote]
This alone opens a plethora of paradoxical situations. Is it even possible to conclusively model a system that understands the world around it including its self? If such a system predicts the future then that prediction alone surely influences the actual outcome, invalidating the initial prediction.[/quote]

xx matty xx:

Yeah, it was more of a rhetorical question.

An absolute and complete understanding of the universe, if possible, would allow you to predict the outcome of anything and everything; runeite was correct. You would be able to predict the outcome of everything, because you would be able to take into effect the quantum mechanics involved with changing the outcome. I seem to have missed the point of your post in my other post (now deleted), my apologies.

item.title: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

runeite51:

So in reality, nothing is actually spontaneous. Even computer functions meant to generate a random number aren’t completely random. With that said, if you had an absolute understanding of the universe, then you should be able to predict the outcome of everything.

This alone opens a plethora of paradoxical situations. Is it even possible to conclusively model a system that understands the world around it including its self? If such a system predicts the future then that prediction alone surely influences the actual outcome, invalidating the initial prediction.

item.source: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?

item.title: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“runeite51, post:20, topic:534054”]It really depends on what you constitute as random. I think we consider spontaneous as something we can’t explain. Example: You might think someone is random. Take that person to a psychologist, and they’ll explain that person’s random actions. If you roll a die, you’d say there is a random chance of it being from 1 to 6. Would you still consider it random if you had a complete understanding of the universe and physics, and knew if you factored everything around you which side it would land on?

So in reality, nothing is actually spontaneous. Even computer functions meant to generate a random number aren’t completely random. With that said, if you had an absolute understanding of the universe, then you should be able to predict the outcome of everything.

But just because everything can be predicted, doesn’t mean we don’t have free will, because we ourselves can’t predict what will happen. So yes, we do have a choice, but at the same time, it’s possible those choices can be/have been predicted.[/quote]
Rep++.

Read full topic
item.source: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?

item.title: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?
item.dc:creator: @runeite51 runeite51
item.description:
@runeite51 wrote:

It really depends on what you constitute as random. I think we consider spontaneous as something we can’t explain. Example: You might think someone is random. Take that person to a psychologist, and they’ll explain that person’s random actions. If you roll a die, you’d say there is a random chance of it being from 1 to 6. Would you still consider it random if you had a complete understanding of the universe and physics, and knew if you factored everything around you which side it would land on?

So in reality, nothing is actually spontaneous. Even computer functions meant to generate a random number aren’t completely random. With that said, if you had an absolute understanding of the universe, then you should be able to predict the outcome of everything.

But just because everything can be predicted, doesn’t mean we don’t have free will, because we ourselves can’t predict what will happen. So yes, we do have a choice, but at the same time, it’s possible those choices can be/have been predicted.

Read full topic
item.source: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?

item.title: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Nope. You have free will/a choice. The only difference is when you make a choice an infinite number of universes are created in which you made a different choice. I also believe if you can predict the first two instants after the big bang you can predict any event in the universe. We are all a product of our environment and if you can predict the environment and the effect on people then you can predict every event.

Read full topic
item.source: Do we really have a choice in life?/ do we determine what we are going to do?
